space

Various Missions: Earth has been extensively studied by numerous satellites and missions, including: Landsat Program: A series of Earth-observing satellites that monitor land use, vegetation, and climate change. GOES Satellites: Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellites that provide real-time weather data. ICESat and ICESat-2: Missions that measured polar ice thickness and changes in ice mass.

Astronomical and Orbital Data

Star Type: G-type (Sun)

Distance from the Sun: 1 AU (approximately 149.6 million kilometers)

Orbital Period: 365.25 days

Eccentricity: 0.0167 (almost circular orbit)

Axial Tilt: 23.5 degrees

Rotation Period: 24 hours

Geological Data

Surface Composition: Silicate rocks, metallic core, volcanic plains

Crust Thickness: ~35 km (22 miles)

Core: Large metallic core (75% of radius)

Seismic Activity: Minimal

Hydrological Data

Liquid Water: None

Ice Presence: Water ice in permanently shadowed polar craters

Subsurface Water: None detected

Environmental Data

Climate: Extreme temperature variations; no weather systems

Solar Irradiance: High due to proximity to the Sun

Albedo: ~0.11 (low reflectivity)

Atmospheric Data

Atmosphere: Extremely thin (exosphere)

Major Gases: Oxygen, sodium, hydrogen, helium, potassium

Surface Pressure: ~10^-15 atm

Average Temperature: -173°C at night to 427°C during the day

Radiation: High cosmic radiation, weak magnetic field

Biological and Biochemical Data

Life Potential: None; extreme conditions inhibit life.

Habitability Indicators: No liquid water or nutrients available.

Energy and Resource Data

Energy Sources: High solar energy potential

Key Elements: Iron, sulfur, magnesium; no chemical energy sources detected
